(2)	An event approved and sanctioned by the city occurring on city or public property, or an event in which the city's personnel oversees such event if properly permitted. 
(3)	An event of a bona fide nonprofit civic organization if properly permitted. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 5-1, 6-12-17)
 
Sec. 10-122. Investigative and administrative costs.
(a)	Each application for a license under this chapter shall be accompanied by a check or cash in the amount of $150.00 for investigative and administrative costs. This amount may be changed by the mayor and council from time to time by ordinance. 
(b)	The fee shall not be refundable if the license is denied or if the licensee withdraws the application. 
(c)	Anyone applying for more than one license shall pay only one investigative and administrative fee. 
(d)	Any applicant for a new license under this article that already holds an existing license shall have the investigative and administrative fee waived. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 5-2, 6-12-17)
 
Sec. 10-123. Hours and days of sale.
(a)	Beer and/or wine shall only be sold for consumption on the premises between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. 
(b)	Beer and/or wine shall only be sold for consumption on the premises between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on Sunday in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served and in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging. 
(c)	No beer and/or wine shall be sold for consumption at any time in violation of any local ordinance or regulation or of any special order of the mayor and city council. 
(d)	Beer and/or wine may be sold for consumption on the premises from 11:00 p.m. to 2:00 a.m. on January 1 of any year other than any year when New Year's Eve falls on a Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 5-3, 6-12-17; Ord. No. 523, § 2, 9-13-21)
 
Secs. 10-124—10-150. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VI. PACKAGE STORE LICENSING; REGULATIONS
 
Sec. 10-151. Type of retail establishment.
No beer and wine shall be sold at retail, except in establishments located in zoning districts in which these establishments are permitted as a conforming use or in districts where an existing establishment exists as a nonconforming use. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 6-1, 6-12-17)
 
Sec. 10-152. Hours and days of sale.
(a)	Retail package licensees may engage in the sale of beer and wine between the hours of 7:00 a.m. Monday through 11:59 p.m. Saturday. 
(b)	Retail package beer and wine shall not be sold at any time in violation of any local ordinance or regulation or of any special order of the mayor and city council. 
(c)	Retail package licensees may engage in the sale of beer and wine on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 6-2, 6-12-17)
 
Sec. 10-153. Investigative and administrative costs.
(a)	Each application for a license under this chapter shall be accompanied by a check or cash in the amount of $150.00 for investigative and administrative costs. This amount may be changed by the mayor and council from time to time by ordinance. 
(b)	The fee shall not be refundable if the license is denied or if the licensee withdraws the application. 
(c)	Anyone applying for more than one license shall pay only one investigative and administrative fee. 
(d)	Any applicant for a new license under this article that already holds an existing license, shall have the investigative and administrative fee waived. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 6-3, 6-12-17)
 
Sec. 10-154. Delivery by retailer beyond licensed premises.
It shall be unlawful for any person issued a license under this chapter to make deliveries of any alcoholic beverages by the package beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 6-4, 6-12-17)
 
Secs. 10-155—10-170. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VII. WHOLESALER LICENSING
 
Sec. 10-171. Special provisions applicable to wholesale purchases.
(a)	Any person desiring to sell at wholesale any alcoholic beverages in the city shall be licensed by the State of Georgia and maintain on file with the city clerk or designee a copy of their current state wholesaler license. 
(b)	No person who has any direct financial interest in any license for the retail sale of any alcoholic beverages in the city shall be allowed to sell at wholesale within the city limits. 
(c)	No wholesaler shall sell any alcoholic beverage to any person other than a retailer licensed under this chapter. Provided, however, this section shall not prohibit the purchase by one retailer of another retailer's entire stock in a bona fide purchase of an ongoing business. 
(d)	No alcoholic beverage shall be delivered to any retail sales outlet in the city except by a duly State of Georgia licensed wholesaler. The name of the wholesale distributor shall be clearly marked on the delivery vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 7-1, 6-12-17)
 
Sec. 10-172. Hours and days of sale.
Wholesalers shall not engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages except between 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. There shall be no sales of alcoholic beverages on Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 7-2, 6-12-17)
 
Secs. 10-173—10-190. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VIII. EXCISE TAXES
 
Sec. 10-191. Tax levied, amount, payment; duties of dealers and wholesalers.
(a)	Scope of section. In addition to all other taxes or license fees heretofore or hereafter imposed upon retail dealers engaged in the city in the business of selling distilled spirits, malt beverages and/or wine, there is imposed and levied upon all hereinafter described dealers within the city an excise tax to be computed and collected as hereinafter set forth. The taxes imposed by this section shall not be levied with respect to the following: 
(1)	Wine sold to and used by established and recognized churches and synagogues for use in sacramental service only; 
(2)	Any sale of wine which is exempt from taxation by the state or under the Constitution of the United States; 
(3)	Wine sold to persons outside the state for resale or consumption outside the state; or 
(4)	Wines or malt beverages which contain less than one-half of one (0.5) percent alcohol by volume. 
(b)	Basis for computation of tax.
(1)	The tax levied hereunder shall be computed on the basis of $0.22 per liter for distilled spirits and wine sold or delivered as hereinafter set forth. The $0.22 per liter shall be pro-rated down on fractional parts of liters, so that each bottle or each individual size container shall be taxed on the basis of $0.22 per liter. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any such licensee to possess, own, hold, store, display or sell any liquor or wine on which such tax has not been paid. 
(2)	Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold from a barrel or bulk container, the tax levied hereunder shall be computed at the rate of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons; where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans or other containers except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces shall be imposed. 
(c)	Computations, payment, duties of wholesale dealer and distributor. The tax imposed shall be computed and payable monthly. Each wholesale dealer or distributor selling, shipping, or delivering distilled spirits or wine and/or malt beverages to any retail dealer in the city shall, as a condition to the privilege of conducting said business in the city: 
(1)	Keep and maintain true and correct records of all sales, shipments or deliveries of spirituous liquors and wine and malt beverages to each retail dealer in the city. Such records are to be preserved for a period of not less than one year and made available on request for the inspection of any duly authorized representative of the city. 
(2)	Collect from each retail dealer in the city at time of delivery of distilled spirits or wine or malt beverages, the amount of tax due under the terms of this section and hold the same in trust for the city until such tax is remitted to the city as herein provided. 
(3)	On or before the tenth day of each calendar month, each wholesaler shall make a verified and comprehensive report to the city which shall correctly show and reflect all sales and deliveries of alcoholic beverages to or for retail dealers in the city for the calendar month immediately preceding the date of said report. Said report shall show the name and address of each retail dealer, the quantities delivered to each retail dealer, the amount of excise tax collected under the terms of this section, and such other reasonable information as may be requested by the city. Said report shall be accompanied by remittance payable to the city for all taxes collected or due, as shown on said report. 
(4)	The excise tax levied in this section is hereby levied upon the retailer licensed to do business in the city and it is the intent of this article to so levy this tax as to require the payment of the tax at the time of delivery by the retailer to the wholesaler, who shall have the responsibility of remitting the tax to the city on behalf of the retailer on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, as hereinbefore required, hereunder is not paid on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, a ten percent penalty on the gross tax plus delinquent amounts shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H.15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release of H.15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. 
(d)	Noncompliance by wholesale dealer; distributor. If any wholesale dealer or distributor fails or refuses to make the reports required herein, the city shall notify such dealer or distributor in writing and if the reports are not made and the taxes are not remitted within five days from the date of such notice, such wholesale dealer or distributor shall be prohibited from making any further deliveries in the city and the retail licensees served by such wholesale dealer or distributor for whom the taxes have not been paid shall be subject to having their license suspended or revoked as herein provided. 
(e)	Unlawful retail sales. It shall be a violation of this article for any person, or entity to sell at retail within the city alcoholic beverages, malt beverages or wine on which the taxes herein provided for have not been paid. 
(f)	Unlawful deliveries. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any wholesale dealer or distributor to deliver any alcoholic beverages, malt beverages or wine to any retail dealer in report and pay any tax levy hereunder to keep and preserve suitable records of the sales taxable under this section. 
(g)	Violations and penalties. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article or who shall assist any retail dealer in alcoholic beverages in the city to evade or avoid the payment of the taxes herein provided for shall be guilty of a violation of this ordinance and on conviction thereof in the municipal court shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, and any such person so convicted shall also be subject to having his license suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 8-1, 6-12-17)
 
Sec. 10-192. Excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by the drink.
(a)	In addition to all other taxes or license fees imposed upon retail dealers engaged in the sale of distilled spirits by the drink there is imposed an excise tax upon the sale of said drinks in the amount of three percent of the total cost of such drink which is charged to the public. Such taxes shall be collected by the licensee under this article and any such licensees shall remit the same to the city clerk on or before the tenth day of the succeeding month along with the appropriate returns showing a summary of the licensee's gross sales derived from the sale of distilled spirits by the drink. Gross sales shall include all credit card sales and those sales shall be reported and taxes collected thereon shall be submitted to the city clerk to the same extent as required of cash sales. It shall be duty of each licensee required to make a report and pay any tax levy hereunder to keep and preserve suitable records of the sales taxable under this section, and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of the tax due. It shall be the duty of every licensee to keep and preserve such records for a period of three years and to provide such returns and reports as may be required by the city clerk. Licensees collecting the tax provided for in this section shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of deduction should be the same rate authorized for deductions from state tax under chapter 8 of title 48 as provided in O.C.G.A. § 3-4-133. The city clerk is hereby authorized to create such reports and returns as may be necessary to adequately provide for the collection of the excise tax provided in this section. 
(b)	In the event the city clerk deems it necessary to verify the excise tax submitted to the city pursuant to this section, for any month, he or she shall notify the licensee of such need for verification and the licensee shall submit a verified comprehensive report to the city clerk, prepared by an auditor, reflecting all sales under this section by the licensee and the taxes submitted to the city. The licensee shall have 30 days to submit such a report to the city clerk following such a request. 
(c)	Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and on conviction thereof in the municipal court shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, and licensees failing to remit excise taxes due and payable to the city as outlined in of this section shall be charged a ten-percent penalty and interest shall accrue at the rate of one percent per month (12 percent per annum) until all fees are collected by the city. 
(Ord. No. 498, § 8-2, 6-12-17)
 
Chapter 14 AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Secs. 14-1—14-30. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. ADULT ENTERTAINMENT 
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 14-31. Application.
The provisions of this article shall only apply to behavior in public. No restriction on behavior in one's home or other private place is in any way intended. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-12)
 
Sec. 14-32. Certain classifications of public nudity not affected.
The provisions of this article shall not prohibit public nudity in the course of a theatrical or dramatic performance, play, drama, ballet or motion picture at any theater, concert hall, museum of fine arts, school, institution of higher learning or mainstream performance house as those terms have been applied by decisions of the state and United States Supreme Courts. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-13)
 
Sec. 14-33. Nudity prohibited.
(a)	Except in the course of a theatrical or dramatic performance at any theater, concert hall, museum of fine arts, school, institution of higher learning or mainstream performance house, no person over the age of seven years shall, at any live public performance within the city display his uncovered genital or pubic area, uncovered cleft of the buttocks, or, in the case of a female, uncovered breasts below the top of the areola. The term "uncovered" shall mean not fully covered with an opaque covering. The term "uncovered cleft of buttocks" shall mean any portion of the cleft of the buttocks which is not covered by an opaque covering at least three inches in width at its narrowest point. 
(b)	Additionally, no male shall perform in public at any live performance within the city with his genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, whether or not opaquely covered. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-14)
 
Sec. 14-34. Live sex acts prohibited.
There is hereby prohibited in the city live entertainment in which any person performs acts of or acts which simulate any of the following: 
(1)	Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual act which is prohibited by law. 
(2)	The touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-15)
 
Sec. 14-35. Establishments subject to regulations.
Any establishment which pays persons to dance or appear live in public in a state of partial nudity, which is defined as a state of undress such that in the case of a female, her entire breast is not opaquely covered, or in the case of male or female, the entire hips are not opaquely covered, for the purpose of entertaining its guests, shall be subject to the regulations set forth in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-16)
 
Sec. 14-36. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Licensed premises means the four corners of and footprint for the building in which the activities licensed hereby shall be performed and shall not include the exterior of the building which shall be used only for the purposes of parking, ingress and egress and not for any of the other purposes related to the license. 
Licensee means the person authorized to provide, offer, perform or present partially nude dancing pursuant to a license issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
Minor means, for the purpose of this article, any person who has not attained the age of 21 years, partially nude dancing means dancing live at a public establishment with less than the entire buttocks covered opaquely, or, in the case of females, less than the entire breast covered opaquely. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-17)
Cross reference(s)—Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
 
Sec. 14-37. Zoning and premises location.
(a)	Premises for which an application is made for the licensing of partially nude dancing at the time of the application and at the time the license is granted, if granted, shall be located only in an I (general industrial) district as the same is now or hereafter delineated and defined by the zoning ordinances of the city and shall not be located: 
(1)	Within 600 feet of any tract or parcel of land which is zoned for residential purposes; 
(2)	Within 1,000 feet of any tract or parcel of land upon which is located a church (defined as a place where at least ten persons gather at least weekly to worship, and have so gathered at least one month prior to the application for license under this article), school, governmental building, library, civic center, public park or public playground; 
(3)	Within 100 feet of any tract or parcel of land upon which is located another establishment which is licensed, regulated or permitted for the operation of partially nude dancing pursuant to the provisions of this article; 
(4)	On a tract of land which shall contain not less than one acre and which shall have not less than 100 feet of road frontage. 
(b)	For the purpose of this section, the term "distance" shall mean direct airline measurement from property line to property line, using the closest property line of the parcels of land involved. The term "parcel of land" means any tract of land capable of being described by location and boundary and designated and used or to be used as a unit. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-20)
Cross reference(s)—Zoning, app. A. 
 
Secs. 14-38—14-60. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
 
Sec. 14-61. Required.
It shall be unlawful to provide, offer, perform, present or allow to be provided, offered, performed or presented in a live, public performance, a partially nude dance or dancer or to advertise or cause the same to be advertised in the city unless or until a valid license is issued pursuant to and in compliance with the provisions of this article after payment of the appropriate license fee and only while such license shall continue in force and shall not have been revoked, terminated or shall not have expired. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-18(a))
 
Sec. 14-62. Application.
Any person desiring to obtain a license for partially nude dancing shall make an application to the clerk or his designated representative for a license pursuant to the provisions of this division and prior to or at the time of submitting such application, shall pay a nonrefundable application fee as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk to defray, in part, the cost of investigation of the applicant and the report required by this article. The application shall be referred to the mayor and council for consideration in accordance with the provisions hereof. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-18(b))
 
Sec. 14-63. Fee.
The license fee for the operation of partially nude dancing entertainment or for the presentation of partially nude dancing shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-18(c))
 
Sec. 14-64. Renewal.
Any license issued under this division must be renewed annually not later than February 1 of each year. Such license will be considered for renewal only if the current licensee is in full and complete compliance with all of the provisions of this article and all other appropriate ordinances of the city and state law. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-18(c))
 
Sec. 14-65. Nontransferability.
The license issued under this division shall not at any time be assigned under any circumstances. Any transfer shall require the issuance of a totally new license after such investigation at the time of such requested transfer or assignment as the city may deem necessary or appropriate. If the licensee is a corporation, any change in the ownership of stock in the corporation, or any change in the officers of the corporation or any change in the accrual of financial benefit to any other persons, firms, or corporations must receive the prior written consent of the city or its designated officer or agent. If the licensee is a partnership or other legal entity, no change in the ownership of any interest, however remote or however direct or indirect shall be effective unless or until such change in ownership has been approved by the city or its designated representative. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-18(d))
 
Sec. 14-66. Display of license.
The license issued pursuant to the provisions of this division together with all other licenses issued by the city shall be conspicuously displayed for inspection by patrons or appropriate governmental officials at all times. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(10))
 
Sec. 14-67. Suspension, revocation.
If the licensee or if any dancers, waiters, waitresses, bartenders, busperson, or other employee of the licensee or if any stockholder, officer or agent of the licensee, if a corporation, or if any partner, co-owner, joint venturer, or otherwise related to the licensee shall violate any of the provisions of this article or shall be convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude, whether a felony or misdemeanor and other than traffic violations (unless such traffic violation is related to alcoholic beverages or controlled substance abuse) or shall otherwise fail to comply with the provisions hereof, the license granted pursuant to the provisions of this article may be revoked, terminated, suspended or otherwise limited by the mayor and council after a public hearing is held for that purpose in accordance with the appropriate requirements of the due process clause of the Constitution of the United States and the state constitution which provided that a conviction of any felony or crime involving moral turpitude of an employee of an establishment licensed under this article shall be grounds for revocation of the licensed establishments, in which case the conviction shall also be grounds for revocation of the license of the establishment. Upon any such violation by the licensee shall in the opinion of the mayor and council constitute such a violation and shall immediately place in jeopardy or pose an immediate threat to person or to property, sufficient to justify immediate action, the mayor and council may by informally providing limited due process temporarily suspend such license provided they shall within a period of 30 days thereafter, proceed to afford to the licensee a full due process hearing. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-21)
 
Secs. 14-68—14-90. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. OPERATIONAL REGULATIONS
 
Sec. 14-91. Compliance with law.
Any partially nude dance establishment licensed in the city must be operated pursuant to and in strict conformity with all applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations and in addition, in strict conformity with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19)
 
Sec. 14-92. Employment of minors.
The licensee under this article shall not employ, engage or contract with any person to perform or to render services in conjunction with the licensed premises who is under the age of 21 years either as a dancer, waiter, waitress, or busperson or in any other capacity. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(1))
 
Sec. 14-93. Employment restrictions for dancers.
(a)	Any person employed by a licensee under this article as a waiter, waitress, busperson or other employee of the licensed establishment shall not while so employed or for a period of one month after being employed or at least one month prior to such employment perform as a dancer in the licensed premises. 
(b)	A dancer shall not at any time be employed by the licensee as a waiter, waitress, or busperson or in any capacity for a period of 30 days after having performed as a dancer in the licensed premises or in any premises in the state in which partially nude dancing is offered or allowed. 
(c)	It is the intent of this provision that dancers shall perform no function other than that of dancing or providing the entertainment licensed hereby and shall not at any time provide services as waiters, waitresses, bartenders, buspersons or otherwise in or about the licensed premises. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(2))
 
Sec. 14-94. Permit required for dancers.
Any person who shall desire to appear as a partially nude dancer in the licensed premises or who shall appear as a partially nude dancer in any establishment licensed under this article, prior to performing must register with and obtain a permit from the police department of the city and at the time of application must be at least 21 years of age. The applicant for a permit shall file with the chief of police or his designee an application which shall state, truthfully and correctly, the age and current address of the applicant; all prior addresses of the applicant within the immediately preceding three-year period and the marital status of the applicant during such period; any convictions of applicant for violation of federal, state or local laws excluding traffic violations other than violations involving alcohol or controlled substances within the immediately preceding three years; and any other information reasonably requested by the police chief or his designee in conjunction with such application. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(3))
 
Sec. 14-95. Obligation of licensee.
The licensee shall have the continuing obligation and responsibility of ensuring that each dancer performing shall at all times have a valid permit as required by this division. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(4))
 
Sec. 14-96. Employment status of dancers; revocation of permit.
For the purpose of this article, dancers who shall appear in the licensed premises shall be considered as employees of the licensee regardless of the employment relationship the licensee may undertake to define or that licensee shall consider such dancers as independent contractors. The permit of any person as a partially nude dancer pursuant to the provisions of this article may be revoked upon a finding by the chief of police or his designee that material information furnished on the application of such applicant was false or untrue or that such person has been charged with or has violated laws or has been convicted of the violation of any law which, had such violation appeared on the original application, would have prevented the granting of the permit. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(5))
 
Sec. 14-97. Nondancing employees; permits.
Waitresses, waiters, buspersons, or other employees of the licensee shall be required to have such permits and be subject to such rules and regulations as may now exist or may hereafter be imposed by appropriate ordinances enacted by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(6))
 
Sec. 14-98. Employment records.
A licensee shall maintain and retain for a period of not less than three years the names, addresses and ages of all persons employed as dancers in the licensed premises. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(7))
 
Sec. 14-99. Minors prohibited.
No person under the age of 21 years shall be admitted to or at any time be present in or upon the licensed premises. It shall be the continuing obligation of the licensee and the employees and agents of the licensee at all times to take such steps as may be necessary to ensure that all persons in or on the premises shall be at least 21 years of age and shall be capable of proving their age at any time by the presentation of their valid driver's license or other proof deemed appropriate by the chief of police of the city or his designee that such person is in fact 21 years of age or older. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(8))
Cross reference(s)—Curfew for minors, § 50-76 et seq. 
 
Sec. 14-100. Closing hours.
The establishment licensed under this article shall be closed from 12:01 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday and shall be closed from 12:00 midnight Saturday night through 4:00 p.m. on Monday. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(9))
 
Sec. 14-101. Performance restricted to stage, location.
All partially nude dancing or performances licensed under this article and authorized in the licensed premises shall occur on a raised platform or stage intended for that purpose, such platform or stage to be at least two feet above the level of the floor, and no partially nude dancing or performance shall occur thereon in closer proximity than ten feet to any patron or any person whether an employee or otherwise of the licensee. Only one dancer shall dance or perform on such raised surface or stage at any given time. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(11))
 
Sec. 14-102. Personal contact between performers, customers.
No patron, participant or employee of the licensee or otherwise shall touch, fondle, caress or have any physical contact with a dancer at any time on the premises. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(12))
 
Sec. 14-103. Gratuities for dancers prohibited.
No patron shall directly pay, give, or extend any payment or gratuity to any dancer; no dancer shall solicit from or request any such payment, gratuity or extension from a patron. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(13))
 
Sec. 14-104. Illumination of premises.
All areas of the licensed premises shall be fully lighted at all times that patrons are present, entertainment is being provided, dancers are present in the premises or the premises are open for business. Full lighting as used herein shall mean illumination equal to 3.5 candles per square foot within the premises. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(14))
 
Sec. 14-105. Illumination of parking areas.
All parking areas around the licensed premises shall be fully lighted in all parts and at all times shall be fully visible from the public street. No parking shall be allowed in a part of the premises not visible from the public street, so that a police officer may monitor the parking lot without having to enter the premises. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(15))
 
Sec. 14-106. Loitering.
No loitering shall be allowed by anyone outside the premises. The public shall not be allowed in any place outside the building housing the licensed establishment not fully lighted and visible from the public street. The term "loitering" shall mean to linger outside the building housing the licensed establishment for a period longer than five minutes without leaving the premises or entering the building. 
(Code 1976, § 4½-19(16))
 
Secs. 14-107—14-200. Reserved.
 
Sec. 14-201. Definitions.
The following words, terms, or phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Amusement game room means any location where one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are operated that permit non-cash redemption as provided in O.C.G.A. § 16-25-35 (d)(1)(B), (C), or a combination thereof. 
Bona fide coin-operated amusement machine means the same as this term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1 (2) and any applicable regulations of the State of Georgia. 
Location means a business within the city that has complied with the provisions of the ordinances of the city relating to occupation taxes and business licenses. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Sec. 14-202. Issuance of license.
Application for a license for operating an amusement game room within the corporate limits of the city shall be made to the city clerk upon a form to be supplied by the city clerk for this purpose. The license application shall include the following information: 
(1)	Name, address, and age of the applicant, and date of the application; 
(2)	Address or place where the bona fide coin operated amusement machine or machines are to be offered to the public for play and the other business or businesses operated at that address or place; 
(3)	Name and address of the owner of the machine or machines and a copy of the owner's master license; 
(4)	Name and address of any other business owned or operated by applicant within the corporate limits of the city; and 
(5)	List of any other licenses or permits from the city held by the applicant. 
Upon issuing a license for an amusement game room, the city official or employee shall provide the licensee with a copy of this article. The city shall not require a fee for licensure or registration of an amusement game room. A license issued in accordance with this article shall be valid until December 31 of the year in which the license was issued. The owner or operator of an amusement game room shall be required to pay occupation taxes in accordance with section 74-36 et seq. of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Sec. 14-203. Distance.
Every amusement game room in the city shall comply with the proximity provision for business licensed to sell alcohol set out in section 10-58 of the Code of Ordinances. After a hearing, the mayor and council may waive the application of this provision to an individual location if no alcohol is served or sold at such location. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Sec. 14-204. Number of bona fide coin-operated amusement machines at a location.
No amusement game room in the city shall offer to the public more than six bona fide coin-operated amusement machines offering non-cash redemption in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 (d)(1)(B), (C), or both at the same location. After a hearing, the mayor and council may, after consideration of the nature and character of the business, waive the application of this provision to an individual location. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Sec. 14-205. Gross receipts from amusement machines and from business.
Every amusement game room shall keep records available for inspection by city officials that set out separately annual gross receipts for the amusement games and the other products and services sold at the location. Income from the amusement game or games shall not constitute for than 50 percent of the income from the location. Compliance with this section requires both the availability of records for inspection and compliance with the 50 percent of income requirement. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Sec. 14-206. Notice requirement.
Every amusement game room shall post a conspicuous sign with the following similar words: "Georgia law prohibits giving or receipt of any money for winning a game or games on an amusement machine; giving or receipt of money for free replays won on an amusement machine; giving or receipt of money for ay merchandise, prize, toy, gift certificate, or novelty won on an amusement machine; or awarding any merchandise, prize, toy, gift certificate, or novelty of a value exceeding $5.00 for a single play of an amusement machine." 
Every amusement game room shall post the license issued by the city conspicuously and permanently. 
The owner or operator of each amusement game room shall inform every employee of the acts and omissions prohibited by O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35, and by this article, and of the penalties for violation O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 and this article. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Sec. 14-207. Compliance with O.C.G.A. provisions relating to master licenses and stickers for individual machines.
Bona fide coin-operated amusement machines may be used in an amusement game room within the city only if the machines are owned by a person who holds a valid master license in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-17-2, and each machine offered to the public for play has a valid permit sticker in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-17-9. The city official in charge of issuing business licenses shall notify the state commissioner of revenue of any observed violation of O.C.G.A. § 48-17-2 or 48-17-9. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Sec. 14-208. Penalties for violations by owners or operators of amusement game rooms.
In addition to penalties set out in the O.C.G.A. provisions for failure to comply with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 (a.1) through (i), the owner or operator of an amusement game room, after conviction in a court of competent jurisdiction, and a hearing before the mayor and council, may be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)	First offense: Suspension for not more than six months of the owner or operator's license for offering any amusement game at the location where the violation occurred. 
(2)	Second offense: Suspension for not more than 12 months of the owner or operator's license for offering any amusement game at the location where the violation occurred. 
(3)	Third offense: Suspension or permanent revocation of the owner or operator's license for offering any amusement game in the location where the violation occurred, and suspension of other permits and licenses granted by the city for not more than six months. 
Penalties for violation of the provisions of sections 14-203 through 14-207 of this article by the owner or operator of an amusement game room, after conviction by the municipal court of the the city are as follows: 
(1)	First offense: Fine not to exceed $500.00 for each violation. 
(2)	Second offense: Fine not to exceed $750.00 for each violation, suspension of the owner or operator's license for offering any amusement game at the location for not more than three months, or both. 
(3)	Third offense: Fine not to exceed $1,000.00 for each violation, suspension or permanent revocation of the owner or operator's license for offering any amusement game at the location, or suspension of other permits and licenses granted by the city for not more than six months, in any combination of these penalties. 
The fines listed in the penalties for violation of this article may be imposed by the judge of the municipal court of the the city. Suspension or revocation of the owner or operator's license for offering any amusement game at the location where the violation occurred, and suspension of other permits and licenses granted by the city may be imposed by the mayor and council after a hearing. 
Offering one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement games in violation of an order suspending or revoking the license for offering of any amusement game at the location is punishable, after conviction in the municipal court of the the city, by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, imprisonment not to exceed 30 days or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Sec. 14-209. Penalties for violations by those who play bona fide coin-operated amusement machines.
The municipal court of the city is authorized impose the following penalties on any person convicted of receiving money as a reward for the successful play or winning of any bona fide coin-operated amusement machine from any person owning or possessing such bona fide coin operated amusement machine or any person employed by or acting on behalf of a person owning or possessing a bona fide coin-operated amusement machine: 
(1)	First offense: Fine not to exceed $250.00 for each violation. 
(2)	Second and subsequent offenses: Fine not to exceed $500.00 for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 420, § II, 3-12-07)
 
Chapter 18 ANIMALS 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 18-1. Horses, cattle, etc., running at large; staking, driving and leading requirements.
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit any horses, cattle, sheep, goats or other livestock to run at large on the streets of the city, or to be staked so that such animals can go upon the streets of the city, or to drive or lead any such animals or livestock along or on the sidewalks in the city, or to drive or lead any such animals or livestock along and over the streets of the city, unless fastened to a rope, chain or other substantial leading device. Any such rope, chain or other substantial leading device must be securely held by a responsible person during the entire time that such animals or livestock are being led or driven along and over the streets of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 5-1)
State law reference(s)—Livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-2. Poisoning animals.
It shall be unlawful for any person to put out or cause to be put out any poison within the city which is for the primary purpose of killing or causing harm to any dog, cat or other domesticated animal. 
(Code 1976, § 5-6)
State law reference(s)—Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4. 
 
Sec. 18-3. Manner of keeping animals.
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any horse, cattle, sheep, goats or other livestock within the city. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any chickens or turkeys within the city. 
(c)	Should a complaint arise that anyone is maintaining any animal in violation of this section, the owner or keeper of the animal will be promptly summoned to the municipal court. If after hearing the judge or other hearing officer determines that such animal or animals are being held within the city, the owner or other person involved will be given a period of time not to exceed 15 days, to either dispose of the animal or chicken or turkey or to remove such animal or animals from the city. If after such period of time is expired the owner or keeper of the animal has failed to either dispose of the animal or to remove the same from the city, a new citation shall be issued and served upon the owner or keeper setting a time and place for hearing on the complaint before the municipal court judge. If the municipal court judge determines at the hearing that the owner or keeper has failed either to dispose of the animal or fowl or to remove such from the city, the judge shall order such animal or fowl impounded and disposed of. 
(d)	The violation of any order of the municipal court judge, or judge pro tem, under this section shall be considered a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1976, § 5-7)
 
Sec. 18-4. Vicious dogs, other animals.
It shall be unlawful for any owner or other person to maintain or harbor within the city a vicious dog or other vicious animal. It shall be prima facie evidence of viciousness if a dog or other animal, without provocation, fiercely attacks or bites persons or animals not on the owner's premises. For the purposes of this chapter the term "vicious animal" means any animal, including dogs, which shall bite or in any other manner attack or attempt to attack any person within the city; except that any animal that bites, attacks or attempts to attack any person who is unlawfully upon its owner's or keeper's premises or which is provoked to attack shall not be deemed a vicious animal. After a judicial determination by the municipal court that an animal is vicious, the owner or keeper of such vicious animal shall immediately destroy such animal in a humane manner or shall immediately turn such animal over to the county animal control officer, or any official designated by the mayor and council for humane destruction. 
(Code 1976, § 5-8)
State law reference(s)—Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7. 
 
Sec. 18-5. Dead animals, disposal of carcass.
(a)	All carcasses shall be disposed of in a manner which complies with the rules and regulations of the county health department and the rules and regulations of all departments and agencies of the state whose primary purpose is to protect and promote the health of the citizens of this state. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person who owns or has an interest in any animal which has died to leave the body or carcass thereof anywhere inside the city without proper disposal thereof as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1976, § 5-9)
Cross reference(s)—Solid waste, ch. 66. 
State law reference(s)—Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-6. Poultry running at large prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for anyone to allow chickens or turkeys to run at large within the city. Any chicken or turkey found running at large in the city may be impounded and disposed of under the provisions of article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 5-10)
 
Sec. 18-7. Keeping dangerous or wild animals prohibited.
(a)	The keeping, maintaining or housing of dangerous or wild animals within the city is hereby prohibited, and each day of the violation of this section shall be a separate offense. 
(b)	For purposes of this section, dangerous or wild animals shall be defined as: Pit Bull or Pit Bull Terrier or any mixed breed of dog which contains an element of a Pit Bull dog, venomous snakes or other reptiles, alligators, crocodiles, poisonous spiders, birds of prey, wild cats, apes larger than chimpanzees, wild boars, bears, wolves, foxes, and poisonous amphibians. 
(c)	Residents shall have seven calendar days to remove said animal from the City of Rossville after being notified of city code. 
(d)	An animal control officer or any law enforcement officer may immediately impound any vicious animal found to be kept, maintained, or housed in the City of Rossville and issue a citation to the property owner where the animal is found to be kept, maintained, or housed if said animal had attacked or bit another person or animal not on the owners property, or if they have not complied with this Code. 
(e)	The city court shall fine the offender not less than $50.00 for the first offense, not less than $200.00 for the second offense, and not less than $750.00 for the third offense or any offense thereafter. 
(Code 1976, § 5-11; Ord. No. 428, 8-11-08)
State law reference(s)—Wild animals, O.C.G.A. § 27-5-4 et seq.; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7. 
 
Secs. 18-8—18-40. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. DOMESTICATED ANIMALS
 
Sec. 18-41. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Animal means any domesticated dog, cat, raccoon, skunk, opossum or squirrel. 
County animal control officer and/or control officer means such person as designated by the county board of commissioners and/or the city as an official or officer whose primary responsibility is to enforce the animal control ordinances of the county, and/or of the city; to assist in enforcing the animal control ordinances of the various municipalities within the county and/or city; to maintain the animal pound of the county and/or city; and/or to catch, collect or otherwise pick up animals in the county and/or city which are in violation of the ordinances of the county and/or city and in the respective municipalities within the county which are in violation of the ordinances of the respective municipalities. 
Licensed veterinarian is a person with a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine Degree licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the State of Georgia or in the State of Tennessee. 
Nuisance means, but is not limited to, defecation, urination, disturbing the peace, destroying private property, emitting noxious or offensive odors, emitting noxious or offensive sounds and noises, or otherwise endangering or offending the well-being of the inhabitants of the city. 
Owner of an animal is a person who owns, harbors or keeps or knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about his premises for more than five days. 
Premises means a parcel of land and the structures thereon. 
Registered animal shall mean an animal licensed by the city as provided in this article. 
Vaccination is protection against rabies by inoculation with antirabies vaccine, given in an amount sufficient to provide immunity from rabies for a minimum of one year. 
Vicious animal means any animal which shall bite or in any other manner attack or attempt to attack any person within the city; except that any animal that bites, attacks or attempts to attack any person unlawfully upon its owner's or keeper's premises, or which is provoked to attack, shall not be deemed a vicious animal. 
(Code 1976, § 5-21)
Cross reference(s)—Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
 
Sec. 18-42. Identification tag required.
(a)	All animals over 90 days old within the city shall wear a collar or harness to which is attached a metal identification tag of the kind hereinafter prescribed. Identification tags will be provided by the city upon presentation of a certificate of inoculation or vaccination for rabies to an employee of the city designated by the city clerk at the city hall and upon a payment of a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. The application for the identification tag shall state the name and address of the owner and the name, breed, age, color and sex of such animal. The license so granted by the city shall expire on June 30 of each calendar year and shall be renewed on or before July 1 of each year. 
(b)	Animals belonging to nonresidents of the city who do not keep such animals within the city for 15 consecutive days shall be exempt from the provisions of this section; provided, however, all the other provisions of this chapter must be complied with. 
(c)	All moneys collected for the issuance of identification tags and licenses shall go into the city treasury to help defray the expense of animal and fowl control. 
(Code 1976, § 5-22)
State law reference(s)—Rabies inoculation tags, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6. 
 
Sec. 18-43. Inoculation.
All animals over 90 days old within the city shall be inoculated annually so as to provide immunity from rabies for a period of at least one year. All inoculations shall be administered by a licensed veterinarian or an authorized representative of the public health department. 
(Code 1976, § 5-23)
State law reference(s)—Inoculation of dogs and cats against rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6. 
 
Sec. 18-44. Tags.
(a)	Each city identification tag shall be so contrived as to permit it to be securely attached to the animal's collar or harness and shall have its respective number, the year in which issued and the words "City of Rossville" indented and impressed thereon. The design or color of such tags shall be varied from year to year so as to permit easy ascertainment as to whether or not the tag is current. 
(b)	A valid city identification tag shall be securely attached to the animal's collar or harness, which collar or harness must be secured to and on the animal at all times. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner to see that the same is so attached and secured at all times. 
(c)	A valid rabies vaccination tag shall be securely attached to the animal's collar or harness, which collar or harness must be secured to and on the animal at all times. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner to see that the same is so attached and secured at all times. 
(Code 1976, § 5-24)
State law reference(s)—Rabies inoculation tags, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6. 
 
Sec. 18-45. Record of tags.
A complete record of animal tags issued by the city shall be kept by the city. Such record shall show when the tag was issued; the period of time for which the tag is valid; to whom the tag was issued and the address of such person; for what particular animal the tag was issued; and if the owner and keeper of the animal are different persons, then the name and address of each person shall be entered. 
(Code 1976, § 5-25)
 
Sec. 18-46. Misuse of tag.
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove a valid tag from any animal which has been tagged under the provisions of this article, or to place a tag upon any animal for which the same was not issued, or to procure a tag from the city or from any licensed veterinarian by misrepresentation, or to disfigure any tag, or to alter the figures or words upon any tag. This provision shall apply to both the tag issued by the city and the tag for rabies inoculation issued by a licensed veterinarian or an authorized representative of the public health department. 
(Code 1976, § 5-26)
 
Sec. 18-47. Restraint of animals.
The owner or keeper of each animal within the city shall be responsible for keeping it from becoming a nuisance or from endangering or injuring any other person or property, and to that end each animal must at all times: 
(1)	Be tied on the owner's or keeper's property so that it cannot reach the property of any adjoining owner or other public right-of-way; or 
(2)	When allowed off the property of the owner or keeper, be accompanied by the owner or other responsible keeper and be restrained on a leash, rope, chain or other substantial leading device held by the owner or keeper or be in a vehicle driven or parked from which it cannot escape. 
(Code 1976, § 5-27)
 
Secs. 18-48—18-80. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. IMPOUNDMENT
 
Sec. 18-81. Authorized.
Any animal found in this city in violation of any provision of this chapter may be impounded by duly authorized officers of the city. 
(Code 1976, §§ 5-1, 5-28)
 
Sec. 18-82. Right of entry.
Employees and agents of the city charged with the enforcement of this chapter shall have the right to go upon private property within the city for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter when necessary. 
(Code 1976, § 5-34)
 
Sec. 18-83. Notice to owner.
Upon impoundment of any animals for the violation of any provision of this chapter, the chief of police shall determine the ownership of such animal by all reasonable means. The owner, if known, of any animal impounded under the provisions of this article shall be given written notice of such impoundment. 
(Code 1976, §§ 5-2, 5-28)
 
Sec. 18-84. Redemption authorized.
The owner of any animal impounded under the provisions of this article shall redeem the same after receiving notice of such impoundment by claiming the same, providing acceptable proof of ownership, and payment of all fees and charges incurred pursuant to such impoundment. 
(Code 1976, §§ 5-2, 5-3)
 
Sec. 18-85. Redemption period.
Animals not registered under this chapter impounded under the provisions of this article shall be held for a period of three days. Registered animals so impounded shall be held for a period of five days. After such retention period, the animal may be disposed of as provided in this article. 
(Code 1976, §§ 5-2, 5-3, 5-29)
 
Sec. 18-86. Charges.
The charges for the impoundment, keeping, feeding, and selling of any animal impounded under the provisions of this article shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1976, § 5-4)
 
Sec. 18-87. Sale of nonredeemed animals.
(a)	Any animal which is not registered under this chapter impounded under the provisions of this article which is not redeemed by its owner may be sold by the city at public auction. Notice of such sale shall be posted at the city hall and at the place of impoundment of such animal. Such animal shall be sold to the highest bidder for cash. The proceeds of such sale shall be paid over to the city clerk, who shall pay out all expenses and shall hold any balance subject to the use and order of the mayor and council. 
(b)	Any registered animal impounded under the provisions of this article which is not redeemed by its owner may be disposed of by: 
(1)	Adoption, 
(2)	Sale, or 
(3)	Destruction in such a humane manner as deemed appropriate. 
(Code 1976, §§ 5-2, 5-29)
 
ARTICLE IV. HUMANE CARE OF ANIMALS
 
Sec. 18-88. Violations relating to caring for animals.
(a)	Failure to provide humane care. It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal to refuse or fail to provide such animal humane care. 
(b)	Animal suffering. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to permit the animal to live in conditions that cause suffering to the animal, or to directly cause any suffering of an animal. 
(c)	Abandonment. It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal to abandon such animal on any street, road, highway or public place, or on private property when not in the care of another person. 
(d)	Unattended animals. It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal to leave such animal in any location unattended for longer than 24 hours. It shall be unlawful to keep or board animals on property that is not residentially occupied or is otherwise commercial property that is the location of an operating business, such that the property is visited daily during the week and at least once on the weekend. 
(e)	Accumulation of waste matter. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to permit the accumulation of waste matter from animals to collect and remain on the property of the owner or custodian, or on the property of others so as to cause or create an unhealthy, unsanitary, dangerous or offensive living condition on the owner's or custodian's property, or to abutting property of others. It shall be unlawful to allow animal waste matter to run off into any river, stream, lake, pond or other watercourse in the City of Rossville, or to run off onto any other person's property. 
(f)	Failure to provide adequate shelter. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to fail to provide adequate shelter from the elements for that animal, as appropriate to the species. Providing adequate shelter requires providing sufficient food and water, disposing of waste, providing sufficient temperature control (whether heat, ventilation, or cooling) to prevent suffering by the animal, and not maintaining conditions conducive to disease and infection. 
(g)	Unsanitary, dangerous or offensive conditions. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to permit or cause unsanitary, dangerous or offensive conditions by virtue of the size or number of animals maintained at a single location or due to the inadequacy of the facilities. 
(h)	Rabies tag. Dogs and cats shall wear current, valid rabies tags attached to their collars at all times, except when removal is necessary for cleaning, grooming or other veterinary care. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of a dog or cat to allow the animal to be outdoors without wearing a collar with a current rabies tag showing that the animal has been inoculated for rabies within one year of any such time as the rabies tag may be checked. 
(i)	Proper disposal. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to fail to properly dispose of that animal upon its death. Proper disposal means in a method provided by the Georgia Code at O.C.G.A. § 4-5-5, and includes burning, incineration, burial or rendering of the carcass within 24 hours after death or discovery. Dead animals that are buried must be buried at least three feet below the ground level, have not less than three feet of earth over the carcass, and must not contaminate ground water or surface water. 
(j)	Separate violation per animal. Each animal kept in violation of this section shall count as a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 2-8-21)
 
Sec. 18-89. Sick, injured or contagious animals.
(a)	Impoundment of sick or injured animals. In any situation deemed appropriate by the animal control officer involving a sick or injured animal whose owner cannot be located and the condition of such animal is such that death or great suffering to the animal is likely, the animal control officer may take custody of such animal and may secure veterinary services for such animal. The owner of such animal shall be responsible for reimbursement of all expenses related to treatment and boarding of the animal. 
(b)	Destruction of sick or injured animals. Any sick or injured animal, deemed by a licensed veterinarian to be suffering to such an extent that the humane destruction of the animal is appropriate and the owner of the animal cannot be located, shall be humanely destroyed by the veterinarian in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 4-11-5.1. 
(c)	Infected or contagious animals. Any animal impounded by the animal control officer that is, in the opinion of a licensed veterinarian, infected with a disease likely to cause death or great suffering to the animal, or which is a contagious disease, or which will likely spread to other animals, shall be isolated and the owner of such animal shall be notified. If the owner cannot be located or the owner fails to take immediate steps to remove the animal from impoundment, the infected animal shall be humanely destroyed in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 4-11-5.1. 
(d)	Reimbursement. The owner of the animal shall be responsible for reimbursement to the city for all expenses involving the boarding, treatment and destruction of any such animal. 
(e)	Notification of bites. It shall be the duty of any person bitten by a wild or domestic animal to immediately notify an animal control officer. It shall be the duty of the owner, custodian, or any person having possession and knowledge of any animal which has bitten any person or animal, or of any animal which exhibits any signs of rabies, to notify the animal control officer and to confine such animal in accordance with this article. 
(f)	Impoundment and quarantine. The animal control officer shall be authorized to impound and quarantine dogs that have been bitten by wild animals or bitten by dogs or cats that do not have current records of vaccination against rabies. Management of animals exposed to rabies shall be according to the procedures set forth in the Georgia Rabies Control Manual, latest edition, which is incorporated herein by reference as if set forth fully herein. The protocols for livestock, dogs, cats and ferrets possibly exposed to rabies, as well as the protocols for animal to animal exposure and human exposure shall be enforced as set forth in the Georgia Rabies Control Manual, latest edition. The animal control officer shall be authorized to take any and all steps set forth in said manual up to and including euthanizing and testing of animals. 
(g)	Animals impounded for rabies quarantine. Animals impounded for rabies quarantine shall be isolated pursuant to the procedures of the Georgia Rabies Control Manual, latest edition. If the animal shows signs of rabies or dies during confinement, it will be sent off for testing. If the animal survives and does not show signs of rabies, it will be returned to the owner upon payment of fees. 
(h)	Quarantine/isolation procedures. In certain circumstances, the animal control officer may allow the animal owner to quarantine the animal that has been bitten in lieu of the animal being euthanized and tested. The quarantine period varies depending on the circumstance, as set forth in the Georgia Rabies Control Manual, latest edition. In that case, the animal must be placed in a secure enclosure where no other animal or person can be exposed to the virus which can be transmitted into bite wounds, open cuts in skin, and onto mucous membranes. The animal must be kept in a secure enclosure approved by the animal control department and when deemed necessary may require two layers of fencing, separated by at least one foot. Food must be pushed in from a distance, and the animal cannot be approached by any person. Other protocols for quarantine shall be provided by the animal control officer. If the animal escapes from the enclosure, it will be impounded and euthanized for testing. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 2-8-21)
 
Sec. 18-90. Cruelty to animals.
(a)	Cruelty to animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously strike, beat, abuse, intentionally run down with a vehicle, or cause or inflict unnecessary pain, injury, suffering or death to an animal through any act, omission or willful neglect, except that reasonable force may be used to defend his or her own person or property, or the person or property of another, from injury or damage being caused by a dog; or kill any dog causing injury or damage to any livestock, poultry, or pet animal as authorized by Georgia law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-5. "Willful neglect" means the intentional withholding of food and water required by an animal to prevent starvation or dehydration. 
(b)	Poisoning. No person, except a licensed veterinarian for humanitarian purposes, shall intentionally administer poison to any animal or knowingly leave any poisonous substance of any kind or ground glass in any place with the intent to injure any animal. This provision is not applicable to licensed exterminators using poisons as part of a pest control program or the use of commercial insecticides and rodent baits used to control insects and wild rodents. 
(c)	Investigation. The animal control officer shall investigate complaints pertaining to cruelty to animals. The animal control officer may request the assistance of the sheriff's department or the appropriate law enforcement officers of a participating municipality. 
(d)	Necessary pain. In the case of activities where physical pain is necessarily caused, such as medical and scientific research, food processing, customary and normal veterinary and agricultural husbandry practices, pest elimination, and animal training and hunting, failure to employ the most humane method reasonably available shall constitute cruelty to animals and shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 2-8-21)
 
Sec. 18-91. Enforcement.
(a)	Authorization. Animal control officers and law enforcement officers of the city shall be enforcement officials for this article. These officials shall have the authority to investigating complaints, impound and destroying animals, issuing citations, and take other lawful action as required to enforce the provisions of this article. It shall be a violation of this article to interfere with any law enforcement officer in the performance of his duties. 
(b)	Citations upon affidavit. Upon the sworn affidavit of any citizen alleging a violation of this article, an animal control officer or law enforcement officer may issue a citation to the owner of the animal requiring the owner to appear before the municipal court of the city for an adjudication of the complaint on a date and time certain. 
(c)	Inspection warrants. Animal control officers may apply for search and seizure warrants, or inspection warrants when they reasonably believe a violation of this article is occurring. The officer shall apply to the municipal court only upon cause and with an affidavit particularly describing the place, dwelling, structure, premises, or vehicle to be inspected and the purpose for which the inspection is to be made. In addition, the affidavit shall contain either a statement that consent to inspect has been sought and refused or facts or circumstances reasonably justifying the failure to seek such consent. Cause shall be deemed to exist if there is reason to believe that a condition of nonconformity with the provisions of this article exists with respect to the particular place, dwelling, structure, premises or vehicle. 
(d)	Violations. It shall be a violation of this article to: 
(1)	Fail to comply with any provision of this article; 
(2)	Fail to comply with any lawful order of an animal control officer or law enforcement officer unless such order is lawfully stayed or reversed; or 
(3)	Fail to pay costs imposed by the animal control officer unless payment thereof is lawfully stayed. 
(e)	Multiple animals. When multiple animals are in violation of this article or are maintained in circumstances that violate this article, each animal shall constitute a separate violation, or in the alternative, a higher fine shall be imposed on the single violation. In addition, multiple violations on the same animal shall result in a higher fine. 
(f)	Penalties. Any person violating the terms of this article, or rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, may be punished by civil penalty or by criminal citation and fine, not to exceed $1,000.00. Separate offenses shall be deemed to be committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. Each animal shall constitute a separate offense, and each violation of a specific provision of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 517, § 1, 2-8-21)
 
Chapter 22 BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS 
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 22-1. Fire limits.
The city limits is declared to comprise the fire limits of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-1)
Cross reference(s)—Fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
 
Sec. 22-2. No structure moved on streets without prior approval.
No house, dwelling, edifice or other structure of whatever kind, character or description shall be moved through the streets of the city for any purpose whatsoever without the prior approval of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5)
Cross reference(s)—Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 
 
Secs. 22-3—22-35. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. CONSTRUCTION CODES
 
Sec. 22-36. Adopted.
(a)	That the latest edition of the following State Minimum Standard Codes, as adopted and amended by the State of Georgia, Department of Community Affairs, are hereby adopted by the city: 
(1)	International Building Code (ICC); 
(2)	National Electrical Code (NFPA); 
(3)	International Fuel Gas Code (ICC); 
(4)	International Mechanical Code (ICC); 
(5)	International Plumbing Code (ICC); 
(6)	International Residential Conservation Code (ICC); 
(7)	International Energy Conservation Code (ICC); 
(8)	International Fire Code (ICC). 
(b)	Additionally, the latest editions of the following Codes, as adopted and amended by the State of Georgia, Department of Community Affairs, are hereby adopted by the city: 
(1)	Standard Excavation and Grading Code; 
(2)	Standard Swimming Pool Code (for commercial swimming pools only); 
(3)	Standard Amusement Device Code; 
(4)	International Property Maintenance Code (2012 edition); and 
(5)	International Existing Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 437, §§ I, II, 12-14-09; Ord. No. 502, § 1, 8-13-18)
Editor's note(s)—Ord. No. 437, §§ I, II, adopted Dec. 14, 2009, repealed former § 22-36, and enacted a new § 22-36 as set out herein. Former § 22-36 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.

Sec. 22-37. Enforcement.
The administrative procedures attached to the ordinance from which this section was derived, and which attachment is on file in the office of the city clerk, shall govern the administration and enforcement of the minimum codes adopted by the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 342B, 4-27-97)
 
Sec. 22-38. Permit and inspection fees.
Permit and inspection fees and any other charges imposed or due under the various construction codes adopted by this article shall be as provided in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. 
 
Sec. 22-39. Public utilities.
(a)	No public utility may furnish temporary electrical, water or gas connection, for construction purposes, unless the contractor has been issued a construction permit by the chief building official. 
(b)	No public utility may furnish permanent electrical, water or gas connections until the contractor has been issued a certificate of occupancy by the chief building official. 
(c)	No public utility may furnish power to a mobile home site until the owner has been issued either a building permit or a certificate of occupancy by the chief building official. 
 
Sec. 22-40. Water supply and sewage disposal facilities.
(a)	Building permits will not be issued until plans for water supply and sewage disposal have been approved by the county board of health. 
(b)	Certificates of occupancy will not be issued until the completed water supply and sewage disposal facilities have been approved by the board of health. 
State law reference(s)—Regulations for septic tanks in unincorporated areas; conformity prerequisite to building permit, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.1. 
 
Secs. 22-41—22-70. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. FLOW-RATE RESTRICTIONS ON PLUMBING FIXTURES 
 
Sec. 22-71. Purpose of article.
It is the purpose of this article to require the use of ultra-low flow plumbing fixtures in all new construction or when replacing plumbing fixtures during renovation or remodeling of existing buildings; to require the certification of plumbing fixtures regarding flow rates and serviceability standards; to promote compliance with state laws for the purpose of conserving water; to maintain the integrity of drinking water supplies; and to reduce wastewater flows. 
 
Sec. 22-72. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial building means any type of building other than residential. 
Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building, and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. 
Plumbing fixtures means any toilet, urinal, showerhead, bathroom, lavatory and kitchen faucet and replacement aerators. 
Residential building means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling but shall not include a hotel or motel. 
Toilet means any fixture consisting of a water-flushed bowl with a seat, used for the disposal of human waste. 
Urinal means any fixture consisting of a water-flushed bowl used for the disposal of human waste. 
Cross reference(s)—Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
 
Sec. 22-73. Standards for fixtures.
No plumbing fixture shall be installed which does not meet the standards listed in this section or the state plumbing code, whichever is stricter. This includes all plumbing fixtures installed in newly constructed buildings or when replacing plumbing fixtures during remodeling or renovation of existing buildings, except as noted in section 22-75. The effective date of this requirement for residential buildings shall be April 1, 1992, and for commercial buildings the effective date shall be July 1, 1992. 
(1)	All plumbing fixtures installed as referred to in this section shall not exceed the following maximum water use rates: 
a. 	Toilets 	1.6 gallons per flush 
b. 	Urinals 	1.0 gallon per flush 
c. 	Showerheads 	2.5 gallons per minute, at 60 psi gauge pressure 
d. 	Kitchen faucets 	2.5 gallons per minute 
e. 	Bathroom and lavatory faucets 	2.0 gallons per minute 

(2)	The flow restriction device in a showerhead must be a permanent and integral part of the showerhead and must not be removable to allow flow rates in excess of that stated in subsection (1) of this section. 
(3)	Lavatory faucets located in restrooms intended for use by the general public shall be of the metering or self-closing type, in addition to the flow requirement listed in subsection (1) of this section. 
(4)	The flow rates for all showerheads, kitchen, bathroom and lavatory faucets shall be determined in accordance with ANSI/ASME A112.18.1M-1989 Plumbing Fixture Fittings, as amended; except that maximum flow rates may not exceed those given in subsection (1) of this section. 
(5)	All toilets and urinals shall be certified to meet the hydraulic performance standards for low consumption water closets specified in ANSI/ASME A112.19.2-1990 Vitreous China Plumbing Fixtures, as amended, and ANSI/ASME A112.19.6-1990 Hydraulic Requirements for Water Closets and Urinals, as amended. 
 
Sec. 22-74. Product certification.
The manufacturer shall certify compliance with the standards in section 22-73 by labeling the fixture and packaging as described in this section and providing, upon request, appropriate certification by an independent national testing organization acceptable to the city building official. Effective April 1, 1992, all toilets, urinals, showerheads or faucets shall be clearly labeled to indicate the maximum flow rate or water usage of the fixture at the specified test pressure. Toilets and urinals shall additionally be labeled ASME A112.19.2M, as prescribed in section 8 of such standard. The label shall be affixed to the fixture and remain there until the proper building and/or plumbing inspections have been conducted. Also, the packaging must be clearly marked to identify water use rates when offered for retail. 
 
Sec. 22-75. Exceptions.
Permission for the exceptions listed in this section must be obtained from the building official. New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building may be exempt from the standards of section 22-73 for the following: 
(1)	Showers and faucets installed for safety purposes, such as emergency eye wash stations, etc. 
(2)	Plumbing fixtures specifically designed for the physically handicapped. 
(3)	Fixtures specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or for installation in a correctional institution which may require more water for proper operation. 
(4)	Instances of building renovation where significant plumbing modifications would be required to accommodate the lower flows or for specialized purposes which cannot be accommodated by existing technology.
